data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

Calculate the total revenue and interpret the results.

\[ B = \begin{bmatrix} 120 & 85 & 40 \\ 150 & 95 & 60 \end{bmatrix} \]

\[ C = \begin{bmatrix} 15 \\ 20 \\ 10 \end{bmatrix} \]

A supermarket sells three types of fruit: apples, oranges, and bananas. On a specific Monday, the number of each type sold is represented by the matrix \( F = \begin{bmatrix} 145 & 192 & 103 \\ 152 & 210 & 108 \end{bmatrix} \), where the first row represents the sales at Outlet X and the second row represents the sales at Outlet Y. The prices of the fruits are $1.5 per apple, $2 per orange, and $0.75 per banana.

(i) Define a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the prices of the fruits.
(ii) Calculate the resulting matrix \( R = FP \) to find the total revenue from fruit sales at each outlet on that day.

Write down the matrix \( R \) and explain what its elements represent.

data.output:
At a local museum, entrance fees for different categories of visitors are as follows: $60 for adults, $45 for seniors, and $30 for children. On a specific Tuesday, the museum logged visitors as follows: 185 adults, 73 seniors, and 210 children. On Wednesday, there were 195 adults, 68 seniors, and 230 children visiting the museum.

**(a)** Represent the number of visitors using a 2x3 matrix, \( V \), where the first row corresponds to Tuesday and the second row corresponds to Wednesday.

**(b)** Write a 3x1 matrix, \( P \), representing the price of the entrance fees for each category.

**(c)** Find the matrix \( T = VP \), and explain what each element of the matrix \( T \) represents.

**(d)** Calculate the total revenue collected from the entrance fees for these two days.

Assume the following matrices:
- \( V = \begin{bmatrix} 185 & 73 & 210 \\ 195 & 68 & 230 \end{bmatrix} \)
- \( P = \begin{bmatrix} 60 \\ 45 \\ 30 \end{bmatrix} \)

data.output:
In a small cinema, the ticket prices are as follows: $12 for an adult, $8 for a teenager, and $5 for a child. On a particular Friday, the number of tickets sold for each category was 50 adults, 40 teenagers, and 30 children. On Saturday, the sales were 60 adults, 50 teenagers, and 40 children. Represent the number of tickets sold over these two days using a matrix. Then, compute the total revenue for each day using matrix multiplication.

Consider the matrix of ticket sales for the two days as:
\[ S = \begin{bmatrix} 50 & 40 & 30 \\ 60 & 50 & 40 \end{bmatrix} \]
and the price matrix as:
\[ P = \begin{bmatrix} 12 \\ 8 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} \]

(i) Find the matrix \( R = SP \) representing the revenue for Friday and Saturday.

(ii) Explain the significance of the elements in the resulting matrix \( R \).
